metadata.title: Dysphagia Assessment  Electromyography
description: Electromyography (EMG) is a diagnostic test that measures the electrical activity within a muscle.(1) EMG is not able to determine whether a patient is aspirating, the effect of postural or food texture changes on the safety of swallowing, or the effectiveness of compensatory strategies. EMG is performed with a machine called an electromyograph, which records the muscle’s electrical activity and produces a trace that can be analyzed and compared to normative data.(1,2) Needle EMG is performed with fine needle electrodes that are inserted into the muscles through the patient’s skin. For the purpose of dysphagia assessment, needle EMG is performed on those muscles that are innervated by cranial nerves, such as the muscles of the tongue, larynx, and face.(1) Surface EMG (sEMG) utilizes electrodes that do not pierce the skin, and instead record electrical activity from the surface of the skin.(3) Kinesiologic EMG refers to an EMG study in which the patient performs functional tasks, such as swallowing, and can be combined with video recordings of movements of the jaws, tongue, and/or larynx in order to understand what functional movements are producing each specific electrical output(4)
indications: An EMG study of swallowing might be indicated for patients with the following:
Parkinsonian disorder in need of differential diagnosis(2)

contraindications precautions to test: Skin must be cleaned and shaved prior to application of electrodes for an EMG(3) –Hair, dead skin, oils, and make-up  can interfere with the electrodes’ ability to record muscle activity(3) –Wipe the skin with an isopropyl alcohol in water solution(3)

indications for procedure: Dysphagia is a term that refers to difficulty swallowing and/or a swallowing disorder(8,9) Complications of dysphagia include malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration and aspiration pneumonia, and death(8,10,11) There are two main types of dysphagia, oropharyngeal and esophageal(9) –Oropharyngeal dysphagia  (9,12,13) -Dysphagia involving the oral and/or pharyngeal phase of swallowing -Dysphagia that affects the oral phase only is referred to as oral dysphagia(14) -Dysphagia that affects the pharyngeal phase only is referred to as pharyngeal dysphagia(14) -Dysphagia that affects both oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow is referred to as oropharyngeal dysphagia(14) -Symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia include choking and/or coughing while eating and/or drinking, pocketing food in the cheeks, and loss of food or liquid from the mouth while attempting to swallow(8,12) -EMG is sometimes used for assessment of oropharyngeal dysphagia(1)  –Esophageal dysphagia  (9,12,13) -Dysphagia resulting from an impairment of the esophagus or lower esophageal sphincter -Patients generally report symptoms such as regurgitation and heartburn(8,12,13) -EMG is not used for assessment of esophageal dysphagia
For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709062) –Sarcoidosis(9) (a disease that leads to inflammation of various organs) –Traumatic brain injury(9,13) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of traumatic brain injury, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic) Odynophagia (pain with swallowing) –Following dental surgery or oral surgery, or with acute tonsillitis(5)  Prior cervical or esophageal surgery(9,15,23) –In a study conducted in South Korea with 17 patients with dysphagia following cervical surgery, researchers used needle EMG to evaluate the superior and recurrent laryngeal nerves during swallowing.(23) The researchers in this study found that severe dysphagia was significantly correlated with the presence of laryngeal neuropathy as observed by needle EMG(23) Prolonged endotracheal intubation(16) Zenker’s diverticulum(9,13) (a pouch that forms at the junction of the pharynx and the esophagus)

currently, there is no standardized proc: A team of researchers in Israel proposed a protocol for using sEMG as a screening method for dysphagia;(3) sEMG is usedmore often than needle EMG in clinical settings–Although sEMG is inexpensive, radiation-free,  and seems to be reliable in identifying the presence of dysphagia, its lackof specificity makes it more appropriate for use as a screening tool(3)–Following assessment by sEMG, a patient should be referred to a neurologist or other medical specialist for furtherworkup if dysphagia is indicated(3)–sEMG is the preferred type of EMG for dysphagia screening, as it is noninvasive and provides adequate information forinitial screening purposes(3)-Needle EMG gives more specific information, such as tabulated nerve conduction(3)
equipment: For an sEMG assessment of dysphagia, the following equipment is required:–Four-channel  computer-based  sEMG unit equipped with surface electrodes(3)–Standard surface electrodes(3)–Recording unit with a wide bandpass filter, a bandwidth of 25–450  Hz, and a 60 Hz notch filter (required for feedbackcancellation)(3)–Software that can record a sampling speed of 100 Hz (100 samples per second)-A computer program used for sEMG should be able to calculate the mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum,duration, and range of the muscle activity for each trial(3)-Muscle activity is measured in microvolts (μV)(3)
known physiological aspects of the oroph: Muscles activated during the oral stage–Orbicularis oris superior and inferior(3)–Masseter muscle(3)–Tongue and pharyngeal constrictor muscle(1)-In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 59 children (ages 1 month to 15 years, median age 20 months),researchers found that needle EMG of the genioglossus muscle (an extrinsic muscle of the tongue; gEMG) was a usefulcomplementary evaluation tool for children with dysphagia that provided prognostic information. Researchers found thatwhen a child’s gEMG results indicated neurogenic changes, the child was less likely to progress from gastrostomy tubefeedings to oral feedings; 1/11 of children with neurogenic changes progressed to mixed (nasogastric + modified oral)feeding and 8/11 with nonneurogenic changes progressed to modified oral feedings(25)

Onset of the pharyngeal swallow(1)–Can be recorded from the submental/suprahyoid muscles(1,3)-The activity of these muscles might be recorded via surface electrodes placed midline bilaterally under the chin(1)-Muscles include anterior belly of the digastrics, mylohyoid, and geniohyoid(3)–Submental/suprahyoid muscles should fire simultaneously at the onset of a normal pharyngeal swallow(1)
Duration of the pharyngeal swallow(1)–Calculated by measuring the length of time the submental/suprahyoid muscles continue to fire following the initial onsetof the swallow(1)

Laryngeal movements(1)–Can be monitored via a piezoelectric sensor (which measures pressure) placed between the thyroid and cricoidcartilages(1)-This can provide information about the timing of laryngeal elevation with respect to the other events of the swallow (i.e.,initiation and termination of the pharyngeal swallow)(1)–Airway protection is associated with the movement and strength of the laryngeal adductor muscle(1)

Cricopharyngeal muscle activity(1)–Measured by a needle electrode inserted percutaneously through the neck and directed posteromedially(1)–The cricopharyngeal muscle (at the top of the upper esophageal sphincter) is unique because, in normal swallowingphysiology, the muscle should have a high frequency of tonic activity at rest and then turn off during swallowing (whenthe bolus is passed through into the esophagus)(1)–The EMG trace of the cricopharyngeal muscle is referred to as a “pause”; when the cricopharyngeal muscle relaxes duringthe swallow, the trace shows an absence of electrical activity and resumes electrical activity when the cricopharyngealmuscle returns to its tonic, rest state(1)
electrode placement: Orbicularis oris: two electrodes placed to the right or left angle of the mouth; one electrode above the upper lip, anotherbelow the lower lip; these electrodes record the volitional aspects of the oral stage of swallowing(3,26)
Masseter muscle: two electrodes placed parallel to the masseter muscle on the right or left side of the face (opposite side ofthe face from the orbicularis oris electrode placement)(3,6,26)
Submental/suprahyoid muscles: two electrodes placed under the chin to the right or left of midline(1,3,6,26)

Infrahyoid muscles: two electrodes placed on the left or right side of the thyroid cartilage (records muscle activity of thelaryngeal strap muscles and the infrahyoid muscles)(3,6,26)–The information gathered from the electrodes on the masseter, submental, and infrahyoid muscles relates to theinvoluntary, reflexive aspects of the oral and pharyngeal swallow(3)

For suspected psychogenic or malingering dysphagia: place an electrode over a muscle not involved in normal swallowingfunction, such as the trapezius(3,6)–If a patient is malingering dysphagia, muscles that are normally not involved in the act of swallowing might fire when thepatient strains to swallow(3,6)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -An interview with the patient and/or family members might be appropriate to gather a detailed history of the symptoms and presentation of patient’s dysphagia(17) -Does the patient have a diagnosis that places him or her at an elevated risk for dysphagia?(17) -Recent history of tonsillectomy or dental work?(7) -EMG can be utilized to differentially diagnose dysphagia and odynophagia; a patient with recent oral surgery might be experiencing odynophagia(7)

course of treatment.medical management: Note current and previous medical management of diagnosis; do any of the medical treatments put the patient at elevated risk for dysphagia? Chemotherapy and radiation might result in xerostomia (dry mouth);(16) xerostomia is frequently associated with dysphagia(13,16) Current or previous ear, nose, throat, maxillofacial, cervical, or esophageal surgery/procedures(9,15)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for dysphagia are the following:

In a study conducted in Turkey, researchers compared the effectiveness of a CSE, fiber optic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES), and EMG evaluation of swallowing in identifying dysphagia. Subjects included 24 patients who had had a stroke within the previous 3 months. For the CSE, patients swallowed 10 mL of water and oxygen saturation was monitored by pulse oximetry. Researchers calculated a “Bedside Dysphagia Score (BDS)” by giving patients a point for each sign/symptom of dysphagia observed during the BSE (0–2 was considered normal swallow, 3–6 was considered dysphagia). Researchers found that a BDS of 3+ was positively correlated with dysphagia identified by the FEES and the EMG evaluations. Researchers concluded that the BSE was as effective in identifying dysphagia post stroke as the FEES and EMG evaluations; however, they concluded that best practice for adequately evaluating the nature of dysphagia was to perform a combination of a CSE and an instrumental examination(27)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help Occasionally patients and family members develop their own strategies for managing dysphagia (such as using gravies with all meats or chopping up the patient's food into very small pieces) Patients with prior histories of dysphagia might already be using an altered diet prior to admission(18) Ask the patient and/or caregiver what types of food or drink the patient prefers and/or avoids at home(18)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)(19) -Specific foods? -With specific meals? -Only halfway through meals? -When he or she is distracted or having a meal with a group of people?(11)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -For patients who complain of difficulty swallowing, what exactly is the problem with swallowing? -Does food stick in the throat?(13) -Globus is a frequent complaint of patients with psychogenic swallowing disorders(6) -Globus refers to a subjective feeling of a lump in the back of the throat; occasionally the patient reports the feeling of food sticking in the throat; however, globus is usually not associated with swallowing or eating(6) -Also referred to as globushystericus, globuspharyngeus, or cervical dysphagia(6) -Does the patient cough and/or choke while eating or drinking? -Is there pain associated with swallowing?(3,5)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment(5) (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -When did the symptoms of dysphagia first present?(20) -How frequently does the patient experience the symptoms of dysphagia?(20)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does difficulty swallowing saliva and/or secretions interfere with patient’s ability to sleep? -Document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with a compromised respiratory status are at higher risk of complications (such as aspiration pneumonia) due to dysphagia(18,19) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula?(15) -Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube?(15) (For detailed information on dysphagia in patients with tracheostomyAdults with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID NumberChildren With Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number -When the patient has an uncapped tracheostomy tube, subglottic pressure is reduced and the strength of the swallow is altered(19) -Does the patient require ventilator support? -Patients who require ventilator support are at elevated risk for aspiration during swallowing(19)Briefly assess the patient’s psychosocial status -Has the patient ever been diagnosed with anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, or another mental health disorder? -How does the patient relate to his or her surroundings? Is the patient overly emotional, anxious, or fearful? -If there are concerns regarding the patient’s psychosocial status and he or she is not currently under the care of a psychiatrist or other mental health professional, a referral for further workup might be appropriate -EMG is often utilized with patients in whom psychogenic or malingering dysphagia is suspected because it is a quick, inexpensive test that does not involve radiation(3,6,7) -Review patient’s chart to determine if there is a possibility of psychogenic or malingering dysphagia -History of psychogenic swallowing disorders -Report of globus(6) -History of an eating disorder (e.g., anorexia, bulimia)(6)Briefly assess the patient’s hearing abilities -Does the patient require hearing aids? If yes, does he or she wear them as recommended?  -If the patient appears to present with impaired hearing and is not already receiving audiological services, refer to an audiologist for full workup Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a previous history of oropharyngeal dysphagia?(19) History of psychogenic dysphagia?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient or family/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing (e.g., reflux, cough, weakness, weight loss)

social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Does the patient use adaptive feeding devices? -Does the patient require use of a communication device? -Does the patient require hearing aids? If so, are the hearing aids in good working order? -Does the patient wear glasses? -Does the patient require a wheelchair for mobility? Does the patient require a cane or walker?
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom does the patient live (e.g., family, caregivers)?(15) -Does the patient require feeding assistance at home?(11,15) -Patients who will require an altered diet might require assistance with food preparation from family members and/or caregiver(15) -Is the patient receiving nutritional supplements orally or nonorally?(19) -Is there a feeding tube present?(15,19)

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note excessive adipose tissue of the neck and/or face –Electrodes might not be as effective for recording muscle activity when the muscles are deeper(3) –SLPs must be able to adequately palpate anatomical landmarks such as the hyoid, laryngeal notch, and mandible to accurately place electrodes(3)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Patients must have adequate muscle tone to hold the head in an upright position to accept food and liquid trials –If the patient is unable to independently hold his or her head upright, adequate positioning might be achieved through use of pillows, wedges, or an adaptive wheelchair
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Trials of food and liquid -While the electrodes are recording the activity of the swallowing muscles, the patient is required to swallow substances -Saliva (“dry” swallows)(3) -Thin liquids (usually water)(1,3) -Single sips(3) -Continuous sips(3) -Straw sips -Thickened liquids -Nectar-thick -Honey-thick -Solids -Mechanical soft -Cracker
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Briefly assess communication skills of the patient prior to completion of the dysphagia assessment –If the patient appears to present with speech, language, fluency, or other communication deficits, it might be appropriate to complete a full evaluation of speech and language skills
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: An extensive oral mechanism examination should be completed prior to or asAbnormalities of the buccal and facial muscles might indicate damage to cranial nerve (CN) VII(15) -Is the face symmetrical at rest?  -Is the face symmetrical while making movements (e.g., smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? -Are there any abnormal movements (e.g., twitching, spasms, grimacing)? -Is the patient able to manage his or her secretions?(10,19) -Is the patient’s facial sensation intact?(15) -The patient needs to have adequate sensation of the facial muscles to feel and retrieve any residue during a meal -Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?(10,15) -Does the patient present with slurred speech/dysarthria?(15,18) -If the patient presents with dysarthria, he or she might be appropriate for a full speech/language evaluation following completion of the EMG evaluation -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAbnormalities of the labial muscles might indicate damage to CN VII(15,17) -Are the lips symmetrical at rest? -Are the lips symmetrical during movements? -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to completely seal his or her lips during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly(22) -Is strength normal? -Is lip tissue healthy? -Is there any scarring or cleft? -Is the patient’s labial sensation intact?(15) -If a patient has reduced sensation of either or both lips, he or she is at risk for anterior loss or pocketing of the food on the side of the mouth with reduced sensationAbnormalities of the tongue might indicate damage to CN XII(15,17) -Is the tongue normal in appearance? -Any atrophy? -Any tremors present? -Any discolorations? -Any bleeding? -Patients with dry mouth (xerostomia) as a result of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or medication side effects might present with dry, cracked tongue tissue or a white/yellow coating on the tongue -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to reach his or her tongue to the hard palate during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly -Is strength normal? -If the patient presents with one-sided  weakness of the tongue (or lips), he or she is more likely to have food become lodged or pocketed in the corresponding side of the oral cavity -Following food and liquid trials, examine weaker side of the oral cavity for residueAbnormalities of mandibular function might indicate damage to CN V(15) -Is the patient able to maintain jaw closure at rest? -Is ROM normal? -Adequate mandibular ROM is necessary for the patient to adequately masticate solid foods -Is strength normal? -Is the mandible structurally intact? -Patients with head and neck cancer (especially base of the tongue cancer) sometimes require reconstructive surgeries altering anatomy of the jaw –Hard palate(17) -Is the hard palate intact? -Any signs of fistulas, fissures, or scarring? -Are the height and width normal? -Any prostheses present?  -Is the coloration normal?Abnormalities of the soft palate (velum) might indicate damage to CN XII(15,17) -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)? -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula? -Does the palate elevate sufficiently and equally? -Use a flashlight to see to the back of the patient’s throat during sustained phonation of the syllable /a/ and repeated phonation of /a-a-a/(15) -Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; if fogging or clouding occur, this might indicate nasal emission, which would indicate a referral to the otolaryngologist –Teeth(17,22) -Are any teeth missing? -Are the teeth in good repair? -Does the patient wear partial or full dentures? -If the patient is edentulous, inquire if the patient has dentures at home; if family is able to bring dentures in, re-examine mastication with dentures present -Patients who are edentulous might still be able to eat a regular diet; each patient is different unique -Is there a significant over-  or underbite?
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Briefly assess patient’s cognition –Patient should be able to maintain arousal and follow some type of directions (verbal or nonverbal) in order to undergo an EMG assessment of swallowing –The Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is an appropriate tool for screening for arousal, attention, and other cognitive deficits -The MMSE assesses overall cognitive impairment; sections include Orientation to Time, Orientation to Place, Registration, Attention and Calculation, Recall, Naming, Repetition, Comprehension, Reading, Writing, and Drawing(21) -If language or cognitive deficits are evident on the screening measure, the patient might be appropriate for a complete language and cognitive evaluation

other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Patients with the diagnosis of dysphagia might be at risk for aspiration. Swallowing precautions/feeding guidelines should be posted at bedside, and caregivers, family members, and nursing staff should be educated regarding patient’s risk of aspiration

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The results of a dysphagia assessment with EMG will indicate if the activity of the swallowing musculature is normal or impaired.(1) A typical, healthy swallow would be recorded graphically as a normal waveform with upward deflections and a sharp apex when recorded from the masseter, submental, and infrahyoid electrodes.(3) The following are characteristics of EMG for specific disease processes: Muscle disorders (including myasthenia gravis, inflammatory myopathies, and muscular dystrophies) –Prolonged duration of the swallow(1) –Reduced laryngeal elevation(1) –Cricopharyngeal muscle usually intact for myasthenia gravis; sometimes impaired in myotonic dystrophy(1) –In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with nine patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) with dysphagia and six patients with DMD with intact swallow function, as well as 12 healthy controls, researchers found that the sEMG patterns produced by all patients with DMD differed from healthy controls despite swallowing status (i.e., even those people with DMD who had intact swallowing function displayed altered muscle contraction patterns)(26) ALS –In early stages, delay of the pharyngeal swallow response(1) –In later stages of ALS, absence of the pharyngeal swallow response(1) –Cricopharyngeal muscle becomes hypertonic/hyper-reflexic,  resulting in a delayed relaxation, as well as premature contraction; additionally might notice a shortening of the total duration of the “pause” on the cricopharyngeal trace(1) –Overall, the waveforms of the swallow will appear disorganized(3) Parkinson disease –Pharyngeal swallow impaired in the late stages of Parkinson disease(1) –Poverty of movement in the submental/suprahyoid muscles on EMG(2) –Prolonged duration of the swallow(1) –Reduced laryngeal elevation(1) –Reduced rate of spontaneous saliva swallows(1) –Overall, the waveforms of the swallow will appear disorganized(3) Stroke –Patterns will differ depending on the type and location of the stroke(1) –The following is sometimes observed after stroke: -Prolonged duration of the swallow(1) -Reduced laryngeal elevation(1) -Impaired spontaneous saliva swallows(1) –Overall, the waveforms of the swallow will appear disorganized(3) Gastroenterological dysphagia (such as Zenker’s diverticulum) –Normal masseter muscle waveform(3) –Normal amount of electrical activity of the submental muscles with increased duration of activation and abnormal waveform(3) –Higher than normal electrical activity and longer duration of activation with infrahyoid muscles(3) –Abnormal regurgitation peaks(3) Odynophagia –Dental surgery -Prolonged duration of swallow(5) -Lower than normal activation of masseter muscle(5) -Normal activation of the submental muscles and infrahyoids(5) –Oral infection -Prolonged duration of swallow(5) -Lower than normal activation of masseter muscle(5)  -Normal activation of the submental muscles and infrahyoids(5) –Acute tonsillitis -Normal duration of swallow(5) -Higher than normal activation of masseter muscle and infrahyoids(5) -Normal activation of the submental muscles(5) Class III dentofacial deformity –Lower than normal electrical potential in the masseter muscle during isometric contraction(24) Malingering dysphagia/psychogenic dysphagia –Normal waveforms for reflexively controlled muscles (i.e., masseter, submental, and infrahyoids)(3,6,7) –Involvement of non-swallowing  muscles, such as shoulder tension(3,6)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the successful treatment of dysphagia(17) Referral to gastroenterologist for patients in whom esophageal dysphagia or Zenker’s diverticulum is suspected(17,22) Referral to neurologist for patients with dysphagia who do not have a known underlying diagnosis(17) Referral to pulmonologist for patients who appear to have poor respiratory status and/or function(17) Referral to ENT for patients who present with apparent vocal fold dysfunction(22) Referral to nutrition services/dietitian for patients with poor oral intake or those at risk for malnutrition(17,19) Referral to physical and/or occupational therapy for patients with poor posture, difficulty sitting up in the bed or chair, or difficulty feeding themselves(17)
other considerations: EMG provides information about muscle activation that other tests of swallowing do not; EMG is often used as a complement to another instrumental evaluation of swallowing such as a VFSS or FEES(2) See Description , Indications of procedure , and Guidelines for use of procedure , above .
